channel.title: Camera Man
channel.description:
this program edits the bytecode the rs2client and gives you a lot of control over the 5 fields which control the main screen camera these fields are cameraX, cameraY, cameraZ, cameraPitch and cameraYaw
to compile/build the program, run "ant" on the command line, the build.xml ant file which sort out everything, including downloading the jar, and editing its bytecode
the names of the fields change between updates, they are stored in the fields.xml file, when there is an update, change the names of the fields and rebuild
Credits: Apache Jakarta BCEL - useful to edit bytecode Apache ANT - great program for build automation MissSilabSoft - helped come up with the name "Camera Man"
Here are some screenshots of it, but even with pictures, you cant really show how fun it is to play with, i highly recommend you build and run this iv never done anything like this, so its quite novel to me, but some of the older people in this community might remember similar things from the old game engine
be warned the fields take a bit of time to get used to, and its quite possible to crash the client by setting them to something wierd also, if you dont know the meaning of the words "pitch" and "yaw", look [url=http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Flight_dynamics]here[/url]
my character is the green-haired woman [img]http://img90.imageshack.us/img90/4125/firstpersondg2.png[/img]
this is it zoomed out, but not so much that the fog-of-war removes a lot of the detail [img]http://img296.imageshack.us/img296/5900/birdseyeov4.png[/img]
and this is it zoomed out quite a lot, as far as the JSlider allowed it, of course its possible to go more, but i just capped the minimum value of cameraZ to this [img]http://img175.imageshack.us/img175/7462/satelliteviewuk5.png[/img]
[size=15pt]Post any interesting pictures you make with it[/size]

item.title: Camera Man
item.dc:creator: @belbn belbn
item.description:
@belbn wrote:

I am using this all the time. Whenever runescape updates, the class names change from what they are in the download for this program to some random shit. You must find the right updater output [which is #506 now] and open fields.xml and change the camera class names.

Read full topic

This isn’t still working for anyone else is it? Cause for me the controls don’t do jack for me. I know this is a mini-gravedig, but this looks like such a cool project.

Probably because it is for an older version, and uses that client’s fields.

It can still work, just hook the camera fields. quaters posted them.

item.title: Camera Man
item.dc:creator: @chrisn2323 chrisn2323
item.description:
@chrisn2323 wrote:

[quote=“frank_, post:146, topic:191824”][quote author=the bank link=topic=255496.msg2216108#msg2216108 date=1210201268]
This actually would be a very cool tool to create a first person runescape experience.

If you wanted you could even throw in some paint and canvas changes to make it look like you are holding an axe.

The first person part would be fairly easy. As would overriding the client’s own controls. However, creating your own algorithms for turning may be difficult. It also isn’t very practical.

Perhaps a thought for a latter day.
[/quote]first person would be easy enough to do, i am sure that it will disappoint though because of the tiny clipping distance and the fact that there is no sky[/quote]
No sky would be wierd but couldn’t you remove the clipping if you wanted?

Read full topic

first person would be easy enough to do, i am sure that it will disappoint though because of the tiny clipping distance and the fact that there is no sky

item.title: Camera Man
item.dc:creator: @JavaBean JavaBean
item.description:
@JavaBean wrote:

[code]import javax.swing. ;
import javax.swing.event.;
import java.awt.*;

public class SwingEventHandling{
public static void main(String[] args) {
final JSlider width = new JSlider(JSlider.HORIZONTAL, 5, 150, 125);
final JSlider height = new JSlider(JSlider.VERTICAL, 5, 150, 125);

	class DynamicIcon implements Icon {
		public int getIconWidth() {
			return width.getValue();
		}

		public int getIconHeight(){
			return height.getValue();
		}

		public void paintIcon(Component c, Graphics g, int x, int y) {
			g.fill3DRect(x, y, getIconWidth(), getIconHeight(), true);
		}
	}

	Icon icon = new DynamicIcon();
	final JLabel jl = new JLabel(icon);

	class Updater implements ChangeListener {
		public void stateChanged(ChangeEvent e) {
			jl.repaint();
		}
	};

	Updater ud = new Updater();
	width.addChangeListener(ud);
	height.addChangeListener(ud);
	JFrame fm = new JFrame();
	fm.setDefaultCloseOperation(JFrame.EXIT_ON_CLOSE);
	Container ca = fm.getContentPane();
	ca.setLayout(new BorderLayout());
	ca.add(width, BorderLayout.NORTH);
	ca.add(height, BorderLayout.WEST);
	ca.add(jl, BorderLayout.CENTER);
	fm.setSize(250,250);
	fm.setVisible(true);
}

}[/code]

helpfull enough but not as good as this, you added alot more lol.
nice one tho i like the way you have it to zoom in and out like that.
would work with other things inless you connected it with the webserver.

Read full topic
